importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of Sarkozy's incarceration marks a historic moment as the first French ex-president to go to jail, drawing national and international attention.
The start of Sarkozy's presidential term, during which the alleged campaign financing scandal began, placing the political context of the corruption allegations.
The date of the French highest administrative court's verdict on Sarkozy's appeal in the Bygmalion affair, a critical legal milestone in his case.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The timeline of Sarkozy’s sentencing and imprisonment, marking the culmination of a long-running legal battle.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former French president (2007–2012), becomes the first ex-president of France to be imprisoned.
He is serving a five-year sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 presidential campaign with money from Muammar Gaddafi, via secret links to Libyan intelligence.
Sarkozy was not convicted of personally receiving funds, but of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who arranged meetings with Gaddafi’s intelligence officials.
The case is known as the 'Bygmalion affair' and involves allegations of illegal campaign financing through a Franco-Lebanese intermediary, Ziad Tiakeddine.
Sarkozy is currently imprisoned at La Santé prison in an isolation wing, where he is in solitary confinement with only one hour of daily exercise and limited contact with others.
He has appealed his conviction and is awaiting a final ruling from France’s highest administrative court, scheduled for late November 2025.

The French government, including President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin, has expressed support for Sarkozy, emphasizing the gravity of the situation and the importance of due process.
Sarkozy has denied wrongdoing and claims he is an innocent man, stating that his imprisonment is driven by a desire for revenge rather than justice.
Despite the isolation, he is provided with basic necessities including a small cell, toilet, shower, desk, electric hob, TV, and a fridge, with a monthly fee of €14.
He will have access to family visits, phone calls, and written communication, but remains in effect solitary confinement due to security concerns.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Nicolas Sarkozy, France’s first ex-president to go to jail, begins a five-year prison sentence for conspiring to fund his 2007 presidential campaign with money from late Libyan dictator Muammar Gaddafi. Though not personally convicted of receiving funds, he was found guilty of criminal association with aides Brice Hortefeux and Claude Guéant, who arranged secret meetings with Libyan intelligence officials through intermediary Ziad Tiakeddine. The case, known as the Bygmalion affair, has drawn national attention, with President Emmanuel Macron and Justice Minister Gérald Darmanin offering public support. Sarkozy is currently held in solitary confinement at La Santé prison, where he is in an isolation wing with limited contact, and has appealed his conviction, claiming innocence and asserting that the prison sentence is driven by political revenge rather than justice. The final verdict on his appeal is expected in late November 2025.
title: Sarkozy enters jail over campaign financing - France's first ex-president behind bars
